title: Why the daggiest place in Australia is actually cool
text:
What are these? The lobby of Canberra’s funkiest new hotel, Hotel Hotel. Source: Supplied 
CANBERRA has long been the butt of many jokes. A punching bag for Australia’s more esteemed cities. 
“Boring”, “no personality”, “a place to retire”, it’s forever been likened as a trip to grandma’s house. 
But something’s changed in our capital. 
Could it be that Canberra has actually become cool? While we’ve all been busily avoiding the place, Canberrans have been chipping away at their image and quietly come to the forefront as sophisticated, quirky and somewhere you’d actually like to go. 
Here’s how Canberra got its groove back. 
Braddon 
Once a former site for car yards, Braddon has become Canberra’s epicentre of cool. Hipsters have been working hard to bring funky restaurants, bars and cafes to the area including 86 and Italian & Sons. 
The Hamlet is full of pop up stores and food vans. Eat your way through BrodDog, the Spit Shak, Chasing Mr Morris and more. Eightysix is one of Canberra’s hippiest new restaurants. Source: Facebook 
Hotels 
The 68-room Hotel Hotel looks like something from the Meatpacking district of New York. Its incredible design is the product of brothers Bectar and Johnathan Efkarpidis and it has brought edge and sophistication to Canberra. 
Located in the New Acton precinct, its lobby is home to Monster bar — the go to place for a drink and filled with young hipsters, buzzing with energy. It has been intricately designed with an eclectic mix of furniture and art. 
National Arboretum 
So at first this sounds like something for the oldies. But it’s actually quite spectacular. One of Canberra’s newest attractions, the National Arboretum is a beautiful site built on the grounds devastated during the 2003 Canberra bushfires. 
One hundred forests have been planted, but what is even more impressive is the visitor centre at the top of the hill offering unbeatable views over the city. The National Arboretum is a cool spot for a coffee with a view. Source: Facebook 
New Acton 
Urban redevelopment has been a tough thing to get right. Melbourne’s Docklands has come under criticism for being a soulless ghost village, but Canberra’s award winning New Acton precinct has got it completely right. 
Home to Hotel Hotel, you’ll also find residential buildings, retail, office facilities and some of Canberra’s best restaurants and cafes. 
High Tea 
High tea is back in fashion and Canberra has its fair share of venues thanks to our British connection. But the best one in town has to be the traditional high tea at the Hyatt Hotel . 
Cucumber finger sandwiches, scones and cake are complimented with a glass of the local sparkling and you’ll get to see the famous staff golf caddie uniform. The Hyatt blends modernity and tradition at its famous high tea. Source: Supplied 
This reporter was a guest of Luxury Escapes .
